text: <p>In the first article "The Little Things That Run the World," I was fascinated to learn how many invertebrates there are in the world, as well as why they are so abundant and adaptable. As I continued reading, I was glad to know that there is a conservation movement out there to help protect these valuable species. I never knew that the human species relied so heavily on invertebrates, in that we use them for multiple purposes. In the second article "The Big Things that Run the World," I was surprised to learn that "big" species tend to be neglected by ecologists. That was shocking because I thought all animals would be an important subject for ecologists since every species plays an important role in one way or another. It was disappointing to learn that there has not been a research program to test the functional interrelationships between big and little species, so I hope one day that can change. </p>

<p>The article, "The Little Things that Run the World," emphasizes the abundance of small invertebrates as proven by their sheer combined body mass. Wilson claims that invertebrates are the foundation of life, and are essential to our ecosystems. I feel that this is true to a certain degree, as there are so many invertebrates on Earth that they must have some impact on their community. Those invertebrates that are primary producers would have even more of a profound impact on their respective communities, I believe. These ideas resemble bottom up control, in which the lower trophic levels, in this case the invertebrates, determine the structure and function of the higher tropic levels. The article, "The Big Things that Run the World," Terbough claims that top predators hold the key to stability of the diversity of plants and animals below them. These top predators indirectly affect the levels below them, as demonstrated in a study where the top carnivores were removed, resulting in a dramatic increase in the amount of predators below them. This is resembling of a top down control, where the higher tropic levels determines the structure and function of the lower trophic levels through predation. I agree more with Terbough on this, as I feel that removing top predators would have a much larger impact than removing invertebrates from the community. However, the importance of the big and little things may also depend on the specific community and the interactions within it. </p>

<p>“The Little Things That Run the World” by Edward O. Wilson provided a new outlook on invertebrate importance and their impact on environmental stability. I was shocked to discover that 90% of Earth's biodiversity stems from invertebrates, considering the lack of consideration towards these influential organisms. As opposed to our constant distinction between vertebrate species, we overlook the various invertebrate taxonomies and clump them into one vague, overarching classification. We fail to acknowledge how pivotal these small but mighty organisms are to the stability of nature. Should their immense biomass diminish, the Earth would simply "rot" (Wilson 345). Mechanisms such as returning nutrients to plants to maintain the stability of tropical forests are crucial to maintaining our ecosystems. This resembles the bottom-up hypothesis, where the links lower on the food chain determine the structure and function of the entire ecosystem. Considering that the stability of our world is dependent upon these organisms, I believe that their observation and examination should be met with ample gravitas.</p>

<p>However, “The Big Things That Run the World” by John Terborgh provides a contrasting outlook on this perspective. He, instead, suggests that it is larger animals that ecologists fail to recognize and monitor for their impacts on the ecosystem. Because of their higher levels on the food chain, Terborgh believes they hold the key to ecosystem stability and the maintenance of biodiversity. This reminded me of our in-class discussion on trophic cascades and the influences of top-down interactions, where these larger predators determine the flow of natural resources and energy throughout all trophic levels. Altering a predator’s ability to capture prey or fecundity directly and indirectly impacts vertebrates, invertebrates, and primary producers. Nevertheless, I stand with Wilson’s point of view that it is the invertebrates that require more attention and inspection.</p>

<p>I completely agree that the impacts of invertebrates on environmental and human stability is not discussed enough. I had no idea that we rely so heavily on such small creatures, and would nearly go extinct without them. I feel as though as a society we always tend to focus on the larger organisms, so it is interesting to see an opposing perspective on how significant and important these "little" species are. And even more so, I completely agree that there should be more research on the relationships between the big and little organisms considering the large role they both play in nature stability.</p>

<p>After reading the article titled “The Little Things That Run the World” , I learned about the importance of invertebrates and their massive abundance on the Earth. I found it surprising that the disappearance of humans would have little to no effect on the life of invertebrates whereas human life and most other vertebrate species wouldn't persist in the absence of invertebrates. It is critical that as humans we are aware of our potential to either conserve or destroy invertebrate species. We must take initiative to preserve invertebrate species as they are of the utmost importance to the planet and everything that lives on it. On the contrary, in the article titled “The Big Things That Run the World”, the author points out the impact from a top down perspective claiming that predators at the top of the food chain should be accredited with the success of other species in the world, not the other way around. Evidence is present that predators at the top of the chain have direct and indirect effects on the species below it all the way down to the primary producers. It is interesting to learn about both of these perspectives and how invertebrates and vertebrates coexist in environments. After reading the two articles, I have a new appreciation for the small critters on the planet and will try to be more conscious of their presence. I feel as though Terborgh touched on important aspects of large creatures on Earth, but I do think that historically, they have received more attention from the world of science than invertebrates have.</p>

<p>Hi Lucia, I enjoyed reading your opinions on the two articles. I also found it surprising that 90% of Earth's biodiversity comes from invertebrates. I wonder how scientists are able to estimate the amount of invertebrate species as the range given in the article is massive. I also agree with you in the fact that invertebrates need to receive more attention from scientists. Although Terborgh mentioned that vertebrates are neglected by scientists, I feel as though it is the other way around. There seems to be much more data on the effects of large mammals on ecosystems than invertebrates. </p>

<p>I also found it shocking that humans could not survive without invertebrates, but not vice versa. I agree that it is important to conserve these species, especially because they are rarely thought of and seen. I would add that Wilson touches on a bottom up control, where the smaller creatures of lower trophic levels have a profound impact on the trophic levels above them. This is a stark contrast to the top down control that you mentioned in Terbough's article. I also agree that the larger creates on the earth receive a lot more attention than their smaller counterparts. </p>

<p>Hi Emma, I enjoyed reading your thoughts on the articles. I agree that the top-down control of predators is largely important in ecosystems. I think that there is not enough research that has been done on invertebrate species to fully know their impact on ecosystems yet. Both vertebrates and invertebrates are very important on making the community stable. Both of these authors make valid points, I believe that invertebrates need to be studied more in depth to determine their impact.</p>

<p>I agree that it was surprising how many invertebrates there are out there, and I also find it important that we conserve the creatures that we cannot see. I was also surprised to see that big species are neglected by ecologists, especially because I feel that they receive a lot more attention than invertebrates do. Perhaps all species need more attention. Additionally, I like how you mentioned that you wish to one day see research on the interrelationships between big and little species, because that is something that would be very interesting to see. I think that it could shed some light on the impact of top down vs bottom up control on communities. </p>

<p>Invertebrates act as a catalyst for the growth of populations and their existence on earth, without them, populations would cease to exist. Also, vegetation would die off; this would also eradicate the animals that prey on them. Equally important, invertebrates are more important in the upkeep of ecosystems than vertebrates. For this reason, invertebrate conservation is practicable and inexpensive. I think it's intriguing that the ex-situ preservation of invertebrate species is pretty frugal. The importance of invertebrates is seen as useful for research related to biological studies and public health. Due to all the facts stated in the article, it is evident that invertebrates are much more favored and ecologically beneficial than vertebrates.  </p>

<p>While I agree with Wilson that smaller organisms impact the ecosystem immensely, Terbough makes a great point that removing top predators drastically influences the energy throughout other trophic levels. Although smaller organisms play a part in maintaining our ecosystems, the top predators affect other organisms within them more significantly. Similar to how we saw the trophic cascades in the case of wolves in Yellowstone, predator and prey biomass is altered extensively when vertebrate predators are extracted. Similarly, when placed back into the community, interactions between the organisms are altered and may increase or decrease population size. So while it is invertebrates that keep the ecosystem surviving, it is the vertebrates that maintain the levels below them.</p>

<p>Reading "The Little Things That Run the World" provided a lot of insight on the proportion of vertebrates to invertebrates, and showcases their importance.  The article states that there are 42,580 confirmed vertebrate species compared to 990,000 invertebrate species, which is a ratio of 23:1.  The article also talks about invertebrates and their effect on vegeation, saying that invertebrates, especially in Central and South America, are the "principal  consumers of vegetation" (Wilson 344).  This article highlights how truly important invertebrate species are, and they should not be taken for granted under any circumstances.  </p>

<p>In reading "The Big Things That Run the World", it is stated that 90 percent of the Earth's biodiversity "resides in invertebrates" (Terborgh 402).  Dr. Terborgh states that he thinks the key functions of bigger animals are underappreciated, mainly because they are unwieldy, difficult to capture, and are low in density.  The topic of puma and jaguar predation is also discussed, and how the removal of a certain kangaroo species and affect annual large-seeded plants, which in turn affects jaguars and pumas.  Large seed predators seem to have a direct effect on the diversity and composition of certain tree species.  </p>
<p>I also thought it was interesting how much of the world would cease to exist without invertebrates and how important they are to ecosystems around the globe.  </p>

<p>I agree that invertebrates have a large effect to a certain degree.  As for the bigger animals, removing them from the community would definitely have a larger impact than removing the invertebrates, but they are all important in their own way and would affect the community they belong to in their own way. </p>

<p>In the first article talking about small invertebrates, I was shocked to learn how much biodiversity little critters bring to our ecosystem. I see how small the size and greater antiquity bring about the biodiversity, but it was something I had never thought of before. According to the author, the tiny invertebrates dominate us in both mass and influence, which is another piece of information I never knew. I think that these invertebrates are important; however, especially after learning that different ecosystems stress different organisms, I do not know if this is true throughout the world. In the other article, the significance of large organisms is highlighted, especially within their stabilizing function. Predators in the ecosystem stabilize it through indirect effects, which can be just as important as the direct effects. I think it was very interesting to learn how the smallest and biggest organisms in the environment stabilize the ecosystem differently, although both important.  </p>

<p>I too got a new appreciation for small invertebrates after reading the first article. You are right in the sense that these "small critters" are not thought about enough when it comes to humans and their knowledge. Hopefully, we can be more conscious and do our duty to help maintain the ecosystem. </p>

<p>I like your take on these articles! There are a lot of intricate dynamics within ecosystems, with roles from both large vertebrates and small invertebrates. There is a variation between ecosystems since the authors argue more of a top-down versus bottom-up control, and I see how both can be players in our environment. </p>

<p>I was fascinated to learn as well that invertebrates are much more favored and beneficial than vertebrates. I never paid attention to invertebrates or gave them a second thought, but these two articles gave me a new insight. Similar to another post I commented on, hopefully, humans can do their diligence in protecting invertebrates. </p>

<p>I was also surprised by some facts and statistics in these articles. I think that we have always thought that something that is a predator and 'bigger' within the environment is going to have more effect on it, but the small invertebrates do seem to be keeping many ecosystems stable as well. I like that we are focusing more on things now that we have not before, and learning importance in places we previously did not. </p>

<p>After reading the articles on little and big things that run the world I have seen two differing opinions on vertebrates and invertebrates on earth. To start off, I was suprised to see there are more invertebrates than vertebrates on earth. Invertebrates are extremely diverse, with over 30 million on earth (these are most beetles). Invertebrate niches can be small due to their small body mass. It was surprising to read that we, as humans, need invertebrates to survive, but they don't need us. We could not survive a few months without invertebrates. Because of this, I agree that we need to focus on conservation and preservation of small invertebrates and plant species. Next, I read about big things or vertebrates. Big things sometimes are neglected because they are bulky and hard to study. They are hard to study due to the fact they are difficult to capture, observe, and mark. Due to this, the author believes big things are underappreciated. Predators have a big impact on vertebrate communities, with increased predators in vertebrae areas, there are sometimes more than the environment can sustain. This causes prey species to be severely decreased. The Lotka- Volterra competition, that we discussed in the Community Dynamics unit, shows how competition influences the abundance of two competing species. This article discussed how if there are more predators, this affects vertebrate species dramatically. Big things are also very vulnerable to hunting and fragmented landscapes. These things could lead to erosion of diversity of the species. I believe both small and big species are important and Biodiversity of all animals plays a crucial role in sustaining life on Earth. They are vital for both the environment and for humans. </p>

<p>I agree, Nicole. I also found it fascinating how many invertebrates are in the world. I thought it was interesting that human species relied so heavily on invertebrates and needed them to survive and use them for multiple purposes. I think a research program that would be able to test the interrelationships between big and little species is a great idea and would be very rewarding for both the big and little species. </p>

<p>Hi Jordan, I also found it extremely interesting to see that the disappearance of humans would have little to no effect on invertebrates where human and vertebrate life wouldn't persist with the absence of invertebrates. <p>In the article, "The Little Things that Run the World," E.O. Wilson highlights the importance that invertebrates hold in the entirety of the ecosystem. Something that really stood out to me in this article is when Wilson said, " If human beings were not so impressed by size alone, they would consider an ant more wonderful than a rhinoceros". This stood out to me because what initially sparked my interest in biology and ecology wasn't vertebrates, it was the fact that there are thousands of tiny individuals, many of which posses complex ecologies, participating and supporting the world around us. I'm very happy to hear that there are major conservation and education efforts in effect for invertebrate species, because humans and the rest of the natural world cannot survive without them. I wasn't really surprised about the fact that humans can't survive without invertebrates because for years now I've been hearing and seeing the "save the bees" slogan very frequently. One of the main reasonings behind the Save the Bees Foundation is that humans cannot function without bees. Honeybees alone pollinate 80% of all flowering plants in the United States and their numbers were decline for quite some time. Without this invertebrate, many people and ecosystems would suffer.</p>

<p>In John Terborgh's article, "The Big Thing that Run the World", he mainly uses examples of top down control to defend the position of "the big things" and vertebrates. But what I think some people seem to forget is that invertebrates don't just consist of tiny little prey insects but also consist of larger predatory animals. Larger predatory invertebrates include the giant squid, and the lions mane jellyfish. These species can also be involved in top down control. So I think it's safe to say that both 'the little things" and "the big things" are equally as important in the natural world. In some certain ecosystems one may be more important than the other but they all depend on each other and I think that it's important advocate for both when it comes to research and conservation.</p>

<p>Hi Brikiya, I also agree that it's surprising that the preservation effort for invertebrates is smaller than vertebrates. I think it's important to bring the preservation of invertebrates to light because the are so important to our ecosystem. But I don't think that one is more important than the other. I think there is a balance between vertebrates and invertebrate in each ecosystem and that balance is what keeps an ecosystem stable.</p>

<p>Hi Jordan, I agree that humans should take initiative to preserve invertebrate species. I think it's really important to care for these creatures because they provide so much for us that we're not even aware of.</p>

<p>In the first article, "Little things that run the world", Wilson highlighted small creatures such as copepods and how humans depended on small animals  since they provide an inexhaustible source of scientific exploration. In the second article, “The Big Things That Rule the World,” The importance of big creatures is emphasized, particularly in relation to their stabilizing role. As I continued reading I was able to relate the VC we did in class on Food Chain Disruption and top-down interactions, as in the lecture the authors discussed how the absence of top carnivores leads to a drastic increases in the number of terrestrial  vertebrates seed predators, so that invertebrates, vertebrates and primary producers are affected both directly and indirectly when a predator's ability to capture prey is altered.</p>

<p>Hi Lucia,</p>

<p>I think you made good points. The enormous number of invertebrates mentioned in the article astounded me as well, and I was interested to know how scientists estimate  the  number of these species. Also, I  agree with you that scientists should pay more attention to invertebrates,  since they are vital to ecosystems and and without them the ecosystems would collapse. </p>

<p>In the first article by E. O. Wilson, there was a strong emphasis on the importance of invertebrate species within ecology. Invertebrates comprise most of the world's biomass but remain mostly underestimated for their environmental impact. For the second article by J. Terborgh, there was an alternative emphasis on apex predators as the most impactful species. Top predators maintain ecosystem stability via the indirect effects of hierarchy on balance and increased species diversity. I feel that it is important to take both of these perspectives into consideration when looking at the entirety of an ecosystem. They both act as keystones but with different methods of trophic regulation. It feels similar to the nature vs. nurture debate, where it is necessary to utilize the integration of both concepts, rather than as separate entities, for better overall understanding. We need to consider how the massive percentage of invertebrates serve our ecosystems despite how underrepresented they may be. The same goes for top predators; they serve as top-down ecosystem regulators who are also underrepresented but for inverse reasons. Invertebrates and apex predators hold a considerable amount of weight on environmental balance and should not be excluded from the greater conversation around their importance within ecosystems.</p>

I wish that you had included more information about the big things that run the world so I could better understand why you believe they aren't as important. </p>

They tend to be resilient due to their wide diversity and incredible numbers. We should put more effort into apex predator population preservation rather than invertebrates. Apex predators constitute a smaller percentage of an ecosystem but carry out a substantial portion of the necessary checks and balances to uphold an equitable environment.</p>

<p>Hi Nicole, I completely agree with you idea that more research needs to be conducted on these matters. <p>I thought Wilson's article on "The Little Things that Run the World" was extremely interesting, and I found it to be crazy that there are so many invertebrates compared to vertebrates. <p>Hi Nina, I agree that it was shocking to read about the biodiversity and biomass of invertebrates in the environment, I definitely would have thought it was less. <p>I agree, the first article highlights the bottom-up effect while the second highlights the top-down effect. <p>Hi Kayla, I completely agree with your summary, The "bottom-up" and "top-down" effects are what was discussed in both articles, and there is a highlighted impact that comes when either species is removed, which results in the cascading effects you mentioned.</p>

<p>I agree with you that insect and smaller organisms deserve respect and attention! I also think it's really important to acknowledge their importance to our environment. I really liked how you tied the articles in with our lecture on bottom-up and top-down interactions</p>

<p>I was also surprised to find out just how diverse the insect world is! It's crazy to think about how many insects there are around us. I also agree with your conclusion that both big and little things are crucial to sustaining our environment</p>

<p>Hi Abagail, I was also shocked to find out that there are so many invertebrates compared to vertebrates, and the fact you mentioned about 93% of animal dry weight in a hectare consisted of invertebrates also made me think of trophic levels very differently to before.</p>

<p>The article "The Little Things that run the World" talks about a perspective that many people, especially non-scientist, rarely think of: the impact of invertebrates on ecosystems and ecology as a whole. I was fascinated with the statistics presented indicating the significance of such small creatures. Specifically, that 7x the number of vertebrates are covered by beetle species alone! While this article presented a new perspective for me, I do not know how feel about the statement that without invertebrates, humans and other large animals would go extinct within a year or so. Not that I necessarily disagree with it, but I would need to be convinced with greater evidence before I could support it. With that being said, I did not completely agree with the second article either. Yes both large and small things have major impacts on a community and the dynamics within such community. However, I believe the dynamics themselves and the interactions between different species are what really hold together a community. Afterall, they are what defines a community. I don't agree that removing only big or small creatures from an ecosystem would send the other into extinction. The effects would be great, but with every other level of the community, the likely hood of the system recovering is strong. </p>

<p>As I read the second article, "The big things that run the world," I found myself thinking that, although all levels of ecological conservation are important, biology at a microscopic or even just small level seems to be fundamentally more important. The pure scale of diversity and biomass when it comes to small and micro level biology is staggering and nearly unknowable. In contrast, the ecological effects of larger animals seem to be simpler in a way where we can observe their behavior and impact and make predictions and hypotheses with greater certainty. The world of small biology is a complex soup of ingredients that needs to be just right, and what I argue here is that although large biology may also be a complex and structurally important web, I cannot imagine that most ecosystems at the large animal scale outcompete the systems at the small scale for importance in the overall productivity of the system.</p>

<p>I also agree with the idea that ecosystems are generally more resilient than what we may assume because of our (correct) stance of general caution surrounding conservation, but I disagree with the non-commital stance to how important these levels of ecology are to each other. Our bodies themselves are not entirely ours, and without the other species that we have living inside of us, we would be dead in much less than a few months.</p>

<p>I agreed with most points you made, but at the very end when you say that all organisms are equally important to sustaining an ecosystem, I would have to say I disagree. Since we have learned about how different species can have different values for importance in a system's productivity, I would say that some are more important for sustainability.</p>

<p>I also took notice of the concept of top-down control being discussed in the second article. I thought it was kind of cool to put the concept we learned into practice when reading a published article. It also grabbed my attention that the first article discussed bottom-up control when talking about how larger creatures like vertebrates would feel a major effect of losing invertebrates. It was neat to see the argument for both perspectives and ideologies while discussing a similar ecosystem community. </p>

<p>I completely agree that the field of "small biology" is wildly unknown and needs to be just right to produce all the complexities it does. These complexities extend far beyond what humans have discovered even in modern times. However, it is these same complexities that form the larger biological systems. At a broader scale, they may be simpler, but deep down they are actually made up of small biology. This simply just reinforces your argument that small biology may be of key importance in the overall productivity of an ecological system. </p>

<p>After reading Wilson's article "The Little Things that Run the World," I was surprised to learn about the density and sheer number of all of the tiny things that live all around us. One thing that stuck out to me was the idea of microniches. It makes sense that smaller species like invertebrates will occupy smaller niches. The fact that there is a larger possibility of niches must result in more species. I had never thought of it this way and I was fascinated to learn just how much of the biomass the invertebrates make up. Apparently, there are 30 times more species of invertebrates than vertebrates. This number blows my mind because it seems like everywhere you look in nature there is a different type of vertebrate. The fact that these invertebrates outnumber the vertebrates by so much is mind blowing. Another thing that I found interesting was how much longer they have been on earth. They had a 100 million year head start on vertebrates to adapt to the environment, evolve, and prosper. After reading the first article I started to give more respect to the invertebrates than the vertebrates. However after reading the article "The Big things that run the world" by Terborgh, I can see now that all living things have their role, even the larger animals that we would see at the zoo. One thing that really stood out to me was that the feces from larger animals can contain an entire mini ecosystem about as big as their natural environment. It is weird to see that life can arise from such odd places. It was also very curious to learn about the concept of indirect effects. The impacts of one part of the ecosystem can stretch far beyond just one population, and the impacts on one species can impact the entire ecosystem. Overall, both articles taught me that both vertebrates and invertebrates are essential for a healthy and prosperous Earth. </p>

<p>Hi Lindsey, I like the point that you brought up about the nature vs nurture debate. I had never thought about it that way. <p>Hi Samaris, I like your take on this article. I had never thought about how much easier it is for humans to study microorganisms. I like your connection to the other VC on food chain disruption because the author almost directly describes these sort of interactions. <p>I believe the argument brought forth by "The Big things that Run the World" has the greatest realistic possibility. The idea that keystone species can determine other trophic levels and like the excerpt said can affect biodiversity. I think conservation of larger species is more difficult and costly aligning with the viewpoint in the excerpt.
